raw_text:
Trial begins of Spain's top banker
 
 The trial of Emilio Botin, the chairman of Spain's most powerful bank, Santander Central Hispano, has started in Madrid.
 
 Mr Botin is accused of misusing the bank's funds after he approved the payment of 160m euros ($208m; £111m) in bonus and pension payouts to two former executives. However, the trial was suspended when Mr Botin's lawyer introduced a new set of documents on the day testimony was set to begin. A three-judge panel gave prosecution lawyers until Monday to study the documents, when the trial will be reconvened.
 
 The high-profile case began after two Santander shareholders filed a criminal complaint about the payments to Jose Maria Amusategui and Angel Corcostegui, who stepped down in 2001. Both executives helped Mr Botin orchestrate Spain's biggest bank merger, between Santander and Banco Central Hispano, in 1999. As he arrived at Spain's High Court earlier on Wednesday, Mr Botin greeted the waiting media, saying: "I have full faith in justice." Santander's board of governors strongly reject the charges against their chairman, saying the payouts were legal and made with their unanimous support. But if convicted, Mr Botin could face a prison term of up to six years. Mr Corcostegui, a former CEO at Santander, also asked the court for new evidence to be admitted. In spite of the allegations against him, Mr Botin continues to lead Santander, and was instrumental in the £8.5bn takeover last November of the British bank Abbey National. Since taking over the chairmanship in 1986, he has turned Santander into one of the top ten biggest banks in the world.
llama3.2:1b: Emilio Botin is on trial for misusing Spain's Santander Central Hispano bank funds.
He was accused of paying 160m euros in bonus and pension payouts to two former executives.
The trial was suspended after his lawyer introduced new documents that prosecution lawyers had not yet studied.
The case began after two shareholders filed a criminal complaint about the payments, which were made with their unanimous support by Santander's board of governors.
llama3.2:3b: The trial of Emilio Botin, chairman of Spain's largest bank Santander Central Hispano, began in Madrid, with allegations that he misused funds by paying bonuses to two former executives.
The trial was suspended after new documents were introduced, and will reconvene on Monday.
Botin has strong support from the bank's board of governors, who claim the payments were legal.
If convicted, Botin could face up to six years in prison.
gemma2:2b: Emilio Botin, chairman of Santander Central Hispano, is on trial for misusing bank funds after approving large bonus and pension payouts to former executives.
The trial was suspended due to new documents introduced by his lawyer and will resume with the prosecution having until Monday to review them.
Botin denies wrongdoing and maintains the payments were legal.
If convicted, he faces up to six years in prison.
qwen2.5:0.5b: The trial of Emilio Botin, the chairman of Spain's most powerful bank, Santander Central Hispano, began in Madrid and is expected to be held in early November.
Mr Botin was accused of misusing the bank's funds after approving bonuses and pensions payments to former executives.
He faces a maximum prison term of up to six years for each conviction.
If found guilty, he could face up to 10 years in jail.

The case began when two Santander shareholders filed a criminal complaint about payments made to Jose Maria Amusategui and Angel Corcostegui, who helped secure Spain's biggest bank merger between Santander and Banco Central Hispano in 1999.
Mr Botin welcomed the charges but maintained that payments were legal and backed by unanimous support from his board of governors.

The case was suspended due to new documents introduced on the day of testimony, leading to a three-judge panel requiring prosecution lawyers to study them by Monday for reconvening the trial.

tinyllama:1.1b: The trial of the top banker in Spain, Emilio Botin, began on Wednesday in Madrid.

The former chairman of the Santander Central Hispano bank is accused of misusing funds after he approved payments totaling 160 million euros ($208 million) to two former executives, according to Spanish newspaper El País.
A three-judge panel will reconvene on Monday to decide whether to continue with the trial against Botin, who has remained in charge of Santander since taking over from his predecessor in 1986.

The high-profile case began after a group of shareholders filed a criminal complaint about payments made by Mr Botin and former CEO Jose Maria Amusa and Angel Corcosteguia to the bank in 2001, when they were all dismissed from their positions.
Despite the allegations against him, Botin remains at the helm of Santander, which is one of the top ten largest banks in the world.
The case has shaken investors and sparked calls for greater accountability and transparency in Spain's banking industry.

If convicted, Mr Botin could face up to six years in prison.
